<main class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
	
	<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-container-core-group-is-layout-fd8f9f5a wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained" style="margin-bottom:2rem">
		<div class="wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2026-01-23T12:12:50-08:00">January 23, 2026</time></div>
		<h1 class="wp-block-post-title">The Five Levels: from Spicy Autocomplete to the Dark Factory</h1>
	</div>
	

	<div class="entry-content wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained">
<p>In my last post, I wrote about <a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/2025/12/this-is-a-time-of-technical-deflation/" data-type="link" data-id="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/2025/12/this-is-a-time-of-technical-deflation/">technical deflation</a>. We’re seeing the cost of code is dropping so fast that we need to change our tech debt payment plans. The smart teams are deferring payment on human hours today to pay them back with cheaper AI hours tomorrow.</p>



<p>But <em>how</em> do you actually cash in on those cheap hours?</p>



<p>If you are just using ChatGPT to write your regex, you aren’t really getting the benefits of deflation. You’re just typing faster. </p>



<p>I’ve now seen dozens of companies struggling to put AI to work writing code, and each one has moved through five clear tiers of automation. That felt familiar, and I realized that the federal government had been there first – but for cars. </p>



<p>In 2013, the NHTSA created <a href="https://www.nhtsa.gov/sites/nhtsa.gov/files/2022-05/Level-of-Automation-052522-tag.pdf">the five levels of driving automation</a><sup data-fn="85e444a0-7424-4e83-8264-2d6012e0eeda" class="fn"><a href="#85e444a0-7424-4e83-8264-2d6012e0eeda" id="85e444a0-7424-4e83-8264-2d6012e0eeda-link">1</a></sup>. This was helpful, because while the highest level at the time was only level 2<sup data-fn="66f428ae-650b-4dbc-85a9-6763730cf2c1" class="fn"><a href="#66f428ae-650b-4dbc-85a9-6763730cf2c1" id="66f428ae-650b-4dbc-85a9-6763730cf2c1-link">2</a></sup>, it let everyone have a common language for both where things were, and where things were going.  </p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image.png"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="1024" height="565" src="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image.png" alt="" class="wp-image-595" srcset="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image.png 1024w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-300x166.png 300w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-768x424.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /></a></figure>



<p>Level Zero is your parents’ Volvo, maybe with an automatic transmission. Whether it’s vi or Visual Studio, not a character hits the disk without your approval. You might use AI as a search engine on steroids or occasionally hit tab to accept a suggestion, but the code is unmistakably yours. This is manual labor in a deflationary world.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-1.png"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="565" data-src="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-1.png" alt="" class="wp-image-596 lazyload" data-srcset="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-1.png 1024w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-1-300x166.png 300w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-1-768x424.png 768w" data-sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==" style="--smush-placeholder-width: 1024px; --smush-placeholder-aspect-ratio: 1024/565;" /></a></figure>



<p>At Level 1, you’ve got lanekeeping and cruise control. You’re writing the important stuff, but you offload specific, discrete tasks to your AI intern. “Write a unit test for this.” “Add a docstring.” You could be using anything from copy-paste ChatGPT to Copilot. You’re seeing speedups, but your job is unchanged. You’re still moving at the rate you type. </p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-2.png"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="565" data-src="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-2.png" alt="" class="wp-image-597 lazyload" data-srcset="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-2.png 1024w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-2-300x166.png 300w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-2-768x424.png 768w" data-sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==" style="--smush-placeholder-width: 1024px; --smush-placeholder-aspect-ratio: 1024/565;" /></a></figure>



<p>At Level 2, you’ve got Autopilot on the highway. As a coder, you feel free. You’ve got a junior buddy to hand off all your boring stuff to. This is where 90% of “AI-native” developers are living right now. You are pairing with the AI like a colleague. You get into a flow state; you’re more productive than you’ve ever been. You’re not using chat, you’re getting real mileage out of an AI-native coding tool. But here is the danger: level 2, and every level after it, feels like you are done. But you are not done.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-3.png"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="565" data-src="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-3.png" alt="" class="wp-image-598 lazyload" data-srcset="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-3.png 1024w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-3-300x166.png 300w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-3-768x424.png 768w" data-sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==" style="--smush-placeholder-width: 1024px; --smush-placeholder-aspect-ratio: 1024/565;" /></a></figure>



<p>Level 3 is a Waymo with a safety driver. You’re not a senior developer anymore; that’s your AI’s job. You are… a manager. You are the human in the loop. Your coding agent is always running multiple tabs. You spend your days reviewing code. So much code. Your life is diffs. For many people, this feels like things got worse.</p>



<p>And almost everyone tops out here.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-5.png"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="565" data-src="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-5.png" alt="" class="wp-image-600 lazyload" data-srcset="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-5.png 1024w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-5-300x166.png 300w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-5-768x424.png 768w" data-sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==" style="--smush-placeholder-width: 1024px; --smush-placeholder-aspect-ratio: 1024/565;" /></a></figure>



<p>Level 4 is a robotaxi, and while it’s driving, you can do something else. You’re not a developer. You’re not a development manager either. You’ve now become that which you loathed: you’re a PM<sup data-fn="4b380e85-e1d0-44a9-a746-8a910e704f35" class="fn"><a href="#4b380e85-e1d0-44a9-a746-8a910e704f35" id="4b380e85-e1d0-44a9-a746-8a910e704f35-link">3</a></sup>. You write a spec. You argue with it about the spec. You craft skills (for Claude Code, because most folks at level 4 seem to find their way to Claude Code). You plan schedules. You review plans. Then you leave for 12 hours, and check to see if the tests pass.</p>



<p>I’m here.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><a href="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-8.png"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="565" data-src="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-8.png" alt="" class="wp-image-603 lazyload" data-srcset="https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-8.png 1024w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-8-300x166.png 300w, https://www.danshapiro.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/image-8-768x424.png 768w" data-sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==" style="--smush-placeholder-width: 1024px; --smush-placeholder-aspect-ratio: 1024/565;" /></a></figure>



<p>At level 5, it’s not really a car any more. You’re not really running anybody else’s software any more. And your software process isn’t really a software process any more. It’s a black box that turns specs into software.</p>



<p>Why Dark? Maybe you’ve heard of the Fanuc Dark Factory, <a href="https://www.organizedergi.com/News/5493/robots-the-maker-of-robots-in-fanuc-s-dark-factory">the robot factory staffed by robots</a>. It’s dark, because it’s a place where humans are neither needed nor welcome.</p>



<p>I know a handful of people who are doing this. They’re small teams, less than five people. And what they’re doing is nearly unbelievable – and it will likely be our future. </p>

readabilityObject.title: The Five Levels: from Spicy Autocomplete to the Dark Factory
readabilityObject.content:
In my last post, I wrote about technical deflation. We’re seeing the cost of code is dropping so fast that we need to change our tech debt payment plans. The smart teams are deferring payment on human hours today to pay them back with cheaper AI hours tomorrow.

But how do you actually cash in on those cheap hours?

If you are just using ChatGPT to write your regex, you aren’t really getting the benefits of deflation. You’re just typing faster. 

I’ve now seen dozens of companies struggling to put AI to work writing code, and each one has moved through five clear tiers of automation. That felt familiar, and I realized that the federal government had been there first – but for cars. 

In 2013, the NHTSA created the five levels of driving automation1. This was helpful, because while the highest level at the time was only level 22, it let everyone have a common language for both where things were, and where things were going.  

Level Zero is your parents’ Volvo, maybe with an automatic transmission. Whether it’s vi or Visual Studio, not a character hits the disk without your approval. You might use AI as a search engine on steroids or occasionally hit tab to accept a suggestion, but the code is unmistakably yours. This is manual labor in a deflationary world.

At Level 1, you’ve got lanekeeping and cruise control. You’re writing the important stuff, but you offload specific, discrete tasks to your AI intern. “Write a unit test for this.” “Add a docstring.” You could be using anything from copy-paste ChatGPT to Copilot. You’re seeing speedups, but your job is unchanged. You’re still moving at the rate you type.

At Level 2, you’ve got Autopilot on the highway. As a coder, you feel free. You’ve got a junior buddy to hand off all your boring stuff to. This is where 90% of “AI-native” developers are living right now. You are pairing with the AI like a colleague. You get into a flow state; you’re more productive than you’ve ever been. You’re not using chat, you’re getting real mileage out of an AI-native coding tool. But here is the danger: level 2, and every level after it, feels like you are done. But you are not done.

Level 3 is a Waymo with a safety driver. You’re not a senior developer anymore; that’s your AI’s job. You are… a manager. You are the human in the loop. Your coding agent is always running multiple tabs. You spend your days reviewing code. So much code. Your life is diffs. For many people, this feels like things got worse.

And almost everyone tops out here.

Level 4 is a robotaxi, and while it’s driving, you can do something else. You’re not a developer. You’re not a development manager either. You’ve now become that which you loathed: you’re a PM3. You write a spec. You argue with it about the spec. You craft skills (for Claude Code, because most folks at level 4 seem to find their way to Claude Code). You plan schedules. You review plans. Then you leave for 12 hours, and check to see if the tests pass.

I’m here.

At level 5, it’s not really a car any more. You’re not really running anybody else’s software any more. And your software process isn’t really a software process any more. It’s a black box that turns specs into software.

Why Dark? Maybe you’ve heard of the Fanuc Dark Factory, the robot factory staffed by robots. It’s dark, because it’s a place where humans are neither needed nor welcome.

I know a handful of people who are doing this. They’re small teams, less than five people. And what they’re doing is nearly unbelievable – and it will likely be our future.

Thanks to Jesse Vincent, Justin Massa, Ramon Marc, and Noah Radford (who wrote this incredible piece) for reading drafts of this.

  1. Actually they made four, which was really five because it was zero-based. Then they realized they had to add a fifth. Which was actually the sixth. ↩︎
  2. The 2014 Mercedez-Benz S-Class Distronic Plus with Steering Assist. Who says AI companies have a monopoly on catchy names? ↩︎
  3. Program manager? Project manager? Product manager? Yes. ↩︎

You might want to subscribe or follow me on Twitter so you don’t miss new articles.
